title: CASA and KYC
introduction: This module explores Current Account Savings Account (CASA) products and Know Your Customer (KYC) procedures in detail.

content.value: CASA represents the combination of current accounts and savings accounts, which are typically low-cost deposits for banks compared to term deposits.

The CASA ratio is the percentage of a bank's total deposits that come from current and savings accounts. A higher CASA ratio indicates lower cost of funds for the bank, as these accounts typically offer lower interest rates than term deposits.

items: Lower Cost of Funds: CASA deposits typically have lower interest costs
Stable Funding Source: Less susceptible to interest rate fluctuations
Cross-Selling Opportunities: CASA customers often use additional bank services
Higher Profitability: Lower interest expenses lead to better margins
Liquidity: Easy access to funds when needed
Basic Interest: Some earnings on idle funds (for savings accounts)
Transaction Convenience: Features like checks, cards, and digital banking
Low or No Fees: Many CASA accounts have minimal maintenance charges

content.value: KYC procedures are regulatory requirements designed to identify and verify the identity of customers to prevent financial crimes.

items: Customer Identification: Verifying identity using valid documents
Customer Due Diligence (CDD): Assessing customer risk and expected account behavior
Enhanced Due Diligence (EDD): Additional scrutiny for high-risk customers
Ongoing Monitoring: Regular review of transactions and account activities

content.value: KYC typically requires proof of identity and proof of address from customers.

items: Identity Proof: PAN Card, Passport, Voter ID, Driving License, Aadhaar Card
Address Proof: Utility bills, Rental agreement, Passport, Aadhaar Card
Photograph: Recent passport-sized photograph
Additional documents for business accounts: Registration certificates, business licenses

content.value: The typical KYC process follows these steps:

items: Document Collection: Gathering required identity and address documents
Verification: Authenticating the provided documents
Risk Categorization: Assigning risk levels based on customer profile
Account Activation: Enabling services after successful verification
Periodic Updates: Refreshing KYC information at regular intervals
